BIBLIOGRAPHY
Robert E. Allinson, “The Confucian Golden Rule: A Negative Formulation,” Journal of Chinese Philosophy
Wing-Tsit Chan, A Source Book in Chinese Philosophy
Wing-Tsit Chan, “The Evolution of the Confucian Concept Jen,” Philosophy East and West
Mark Csikszentmihalyi, “Confucius and the Analects in the Han,” Confucius and the Analects: New Essays ed. Bryan W. Van Norden
Mark Csikszentmihalyi, Material Virtues: Ethics and the Body in Early China
Han Fei, Han Feizi
Philip J. Ivanhoe, “Whose Confucius? Which Analects?” Confucius and the Analects: New Essays ed. Bryan W. Van Norden
Joel J. Kupperman, “Naturalness Revisited: Why Western Philosophers Should Study Confucius,” Confucius and the Analects: New Essays ed. Bryan W. Van Norden
Tiziana Lipiello, “A Confucian Adage For Life: Empathy (Shu) in The Analects”
Chengyang Li, “The Confucian Concept of Jen and the Feminist Ethics of Care,” Hypatia
Bo Mou, “A Reexamination of the Structure and Content of Confucius’ Version of the Golden Rule,” Philosophy East and West
David S. Nivison, “Zhong (Chung) and Shu: Loyalty and Reciprocity,” Encyclopedia of Chinese Philosophy
John O’Neill, “AIDS As A Globalizing Panic,” Global Culture
Franklin Perkins, Leibniz and China: A Commerce of Light (Chs. 4 & 5)
Lisa A. Raphals, “A Woman Who Understood the Rites,” Confucius and the Analects: New Essays ed. Bryan W. Van Norden
